dhq:bio.p: Professor Carberry is a fictious person, born on a bulletin board in 1929. He is said to still teach at Brown University, and to be known for his work in "psychoceramics", the supposed study of cracked pots. He is also used by ORCID, Crossref, and now DHQ as a dummy account. His work has been published many times throughought in the intervening decades, most recently in the British Medical Journal in 2016.

dhq:authorInfo.dhq:affiliation: Association of the Friends of Jean-Baptiste Botul

dhq:bio.p: Jean-Baptiste Botul is a fictional French philosopher created in 1995 by the journalist Frédéric Pagès and other members of a group calling itself the Association of the Friends of Jean-Baptiste Botul. Originating as a literary hoax, the names of both Botul and his philosophy of botulism derive from botulism, an illness caused by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum. References to Botul were first made in publications by members of the association and later turned up in texts by writers who were not party to the hoax and thought Botul was a real person. There is now an annual Botul Prize awarded for a book that mentions Botul.

Mrs. Silence Dogood was the pen name used by Benjamin Franklin to get his work published in the New-England Courant, a newspaper founded and published by his brother James Franklin. She graciously translated this sample article from the original gibberish into English.

dhq:abstract.p: Welcome to the DHQ sample article. In this document, you should be able to find properly formatted examples of nearly every potential article element allowed for DHQ articles. For documentation on when or how to use these elements, consult the Encoding Documentation Wiki, available at: https://github.com/Digital-Humanities-Quarterly/dhq-journal/wiki/DHQ-Encoding-Documentation To see what most of these elements look like when passed through DHQ CSS, import the DHQ_Proof transformation scenario and open it in a web browser.

dhq:teaser.p: This is certainly the most exciting article ever written for DHQ.

div.head: 1: Level 1 Heading and a Demonstration of div and head
div.p: By nesting div elements within one another, articles are given a heirarchy of headings which get smaller with each use. DHQ's css creates four distinct font sizes for nested div elements when used properly.

This is actually a new div which could have the lable 1.2: Level 2 Heading, but it uses a terminated head tag. By doing this, you can start a new section without a heading and still validate the document. Most often this is used for introductions and epigraphs which are not given a title by the article's author(s).

div.head: 2.1: Poetic Line Groups and Lines
div.p: An Ode to the Hamster (an example of encoded poetry)A semi-randomly generated sonnet from https://www.poem-generator.org.uk/sonnet/

lg.l: My tiny hamster, you inspire me to write.
I love the way you cuddle, squeak and skip,
Invading my mind day and through the night,
Always dreaming about the furry flip.
Let me compare you to a library?
You are more amazed, unfazed and superb.
Ice bites the debris of February,
And wintertime has the attractive blurb.
How do I love you? Let me count the ways.
I love your bold fingers, smile and eyebrows.
Thinking of your fuzzy smile fills my days.
My love for you is the inactive vows.
Now I must away with an active heart,
Remember my long words whilst we're apart.

div.head: 4.1: Simple Markup Elements
div.p: att formats xml attributes with conventional @ sign: rend
val formats xml values of attributes within double straight quotes: italic
gi formats xml elements with angle brackets: div

code displays in a mono-spaced font and should be given a value for lang as shown here: print("Hello, World!")code is rendered inline with other paragraph text. It should not be used for snippets of code which are longer than 40 characters. It also should not be used simply for mere visual demarcation of words or variables, use hi with rend=monospace instead.

div.head: 4.2: Complex Code Samples
div.p: eg can also be used without an internal CDATA section, but this should only be done when hi is needed to format or hightlight specific sections beyond the language's contextual formatting. The resulting eg will not resist oXygen's format and indent feature, as shown below: =IF(B2>4,"Congratulations", "Sorry, better luck next time.")

Finally, this is an example of eg encoded as quotation using quote and cit, while preserving whitespace with a CDATA section and referencing its relevant source via a ptr after the quotation: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <text> <para>hello world</para> </text>

div.head: 5.1: Typical In-Text Quotations and Citations
div.p: quote where rend=inline: The phrase Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua is typically used as placeholder text when designing websites. This is becuase the somewhat nonsensical Latin mimics the flow of English language in regards to the length of each word in a sentence.

quote where rend=block: The purpose of lorem ipsum is to create a natural looking block of text (sentence, paragraph, page, etc.) that doesn't distract from the layout. A practice not without controversy, laying out pages with meaningless filler text can be very useful when the focus is meant to be on design, not content.

quote and cit using ref rather than ptr: In their first editorial for DHQ, Flanders, Piez, and Terras wrote Welcome to the first issue of Digital Humanities Quarterly: a new, online, open-access journal...a long time in the making2007. Note that the parentheses around the text content of ref are automatically generated when used within the context of cit

quote and cit using ref where ref's rend=offline: Now is the time to make real the promises of democracy. Now is the time to rise from the dark and desolate valley of segregation to the sunlit path of racial justice. Now is the time to lift our nation from the quick sands of racial injustice to the solid rock of brotherhood.I Have a Dream, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

quote and cit where dhq:citRef connotes emphasis and loc is used: Developing a new journal — on a new publication model, with an innovative technical architecture — is not an undertaking for the faint-hearted. That level of challenge, however, was central to the venture from the start: the world may not need yet another academic journal, but it does need experiments in how academic journals are published.
